dn6:16.4: ‘Take the case when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
dn6:16.5: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …
dn6:16.7: They enter and remain in the first absorption.
dn6:16.8: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:
dn6:16.9: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”?’
dn6:16.12: ‘But reverends, I know and see like this.
dn6:16.14: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”. …
dn6:17.1: They enter and remain in the second absorption …
dn6:17.4: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:
dn6:17.5: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”?’
dn6:17.8: ‘But reverends, I know and see like this.
dn6:17.10: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”. …
dn6:18.1: They project and extend the mind toward knowledge and vision …
dn6:18.2: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:
dn6:18.3: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”?’
dn6:18.7: ‘But reverends, I know and see like this.
dn6:18.9: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”. …
dn6:19.1: They understand: “… there is nothing further for this place.”
dn6:19.2: When a mendicant knows and sees like this, would it be appropriate to say of them:
dn6:19.3: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”?’
dn6:19.6: ‘But reverends, I know and see like this.
dn6:19.8: “The soul and the body are the same thing” or “The soul and the body are different things”.’”
